Chapter on Nirvana, Chapter 27 on Nirvana
Just as a turtle hides its six limbs, a bhiká¹£u should restrain his thoughts,
Without attachment, without harming others, in nirvana there is no speech.

As for just as a turtle hides its six limbs, a bhiká¹£u should restrain his thoughts, it is like that divine turtle fearing for its life. If it sees an enemy, it hides its six limbs. It thinks to itself:

If I do not hide my six limbs, I will be captured by hunters, either my head will be cut off, or my front left and right feet will be injured, or my hind left and right legs will be broken, or my tail will be damaged. Now if I do not take precautions, death is certain.
A bhiká¹£u's practice is also like this. Fearing the evil of birth and death, he restrains his thoughts and disordered thoughts, always thinking to himself:

Although one may attain human birth, the time of life is short. If one does not restrain oneself now, one will then be controlled by the evil demon PÄpÄ«yÄn and the desire-realm demon MÄra, the son of Heaven, and they will have their way with one.
Therefore it is said, Like a turtle hiding its six limbs, a bhiká¹£u restrains his thoughts.

Without reliance and without harm, the one who has attained nirvana has no words. One should not rely on the various bonds, attachments, wrong actions, and inversions. If one wishes to rely on something, one should only rely on the noble truths. If one wishes to reach a place of peace and security, it is like a long-term patient who is weak and bedridden, unable to move or defecate. Or it is like an extremely old and weak person who is unable to get up and must be supported by strong men under the armpits. If one wishes to reach a place of peace and security, one will safely reach there.

Sentient beings are also like this. Their faculties are dull and they are not very diligent in profound meanings. Even if they encounter a good friend and rely on a place of support, they gradually escape the realm of birth and death. Therefore, the World-Honored One expounds the teachings for later generations, not relying on birth and death, giving rise to a mind of harm, not relying on anything harmful, and then attaining the path.
Therefore, it is said, Not relying on anything, not harming others.

As for extinction without words, it is like a blazing fire, its light shining brightly, burning mountains, fields, trees, branches, and leaves without leaving any remnants. After the fire is extinguished, there are no more signs of blazing flames.

Ordinary people are also like this. The blazing fire of greed, the blazing fire of anger, and the blazing fire of delusion burn away the roots of merit and virtue, leaving nothing remaining. Having already lost their own blessings, they also cause others to not reach the ultimate.
If one attains arhatship and all defilements are exhausted, the fires of lust, anger, and delusion are never seen again. Having attained the path oneself, one is also able to deliver others.
Therefore it is said, 'Nirvana is beyond words.'
Forbearance is supreme, the Buddha said nirvana is foremost,
Not harboring vexation or harming others is the way of a Å›ramaá¹‡a.

When ÅšÄkyamuni Buddha was a bodhisattva in the past, he dwelled in a deep mountain where there were no people. He diligently cultivated forbearance, restraining his mind internally so that various thoughts did not arise.

At that time, there was a King KalÄpa who went out for a pleasure trip, bringing with him palace ladies and concubines. They amused themselves with the five kinds of music, playing the zither, drum, and flute, singing and dancing to their heart's content. Hearing the music, he became tired and fell asleep.

The palace ladies and concubines each ran off to pick beautiful flowers. They saw the Bodhisattva sitting under a tree, his countenance upright like the color of a peach blossom. Whoever saw him was overjoyed, like the sun just rising, illuminating everywhere, like the moon in the sky with the stars and constellations standing out.
The concubines saw him and rushed towards him, kneeling and standing to one side each.
At that time, the Bodhisattva slowly opened his eyes and looked around. His demeanor was dignified and proper. He gradually guided and taught them the wonderful Dharma.

Unwholesome sexual conduct is a great affliction. If a person is defiled by lust and attachment, they will later fall into the realm of birds, beasts, and pigeons. The foul stench and impurity will lead to a fall into the evil destinies. This is not what the sages and true persons practice.
Sisters, you should know!
Lust and desire will result in the retribution of a fiery chariot and burning charcoal.
In this way, the Bodhisattva used countless skillful means to speak of the defilement of desire.

At that time, King KalÄpa woke up from sleep and looked around. He did not see the assembly of court ladies. He immediately drew his sharp sword, lightly mounted his swift horse, and rushed out to search for them. After a long time, he saw the Bodhisattva from afar, his countenance relaxed, surrounded by court ladies. The king thought to himself:
This person is upright and rare in the world. He must have had sexual relations with my court ladies.
He gave rise to anger and hatred within, his rage blazing without regard for reason, and asked directly:
You are a sage practicing the Way here, have you attained the first dhyÄna?
He replied:
No, I have not.
The king said:

Have you attained the second, third, fourth dhyÄnas, the sphere of infinite space, the sphere of infinite consciousness, the sphere of nothingness, or the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception?
He replied:
No, I have not attained any of these.
The king said:
You are here studying the Way, but have not attained any of these virtues. Why waste your days and months here?
The Bodhisattva replied:
The reason I abandoned my family business and came here to study is to cultivate the concentration of patience.
The king thought to himself:

This person has been studying here for a long time. He has been observing my appearance and knows that I am very angry. That is why he is practicing patience in response to me. I will now test him to see if it is really so.

The method of testing patience cannot be done with food and drink, delicacies, or music. It is only necessary to use the torment of severe anger and pain that injures the flesh to know the present verification.
The king said to the sage:
If you practice patience, quickly extend your right hand, I want to test it.

At that time, the Bodhisattva joyfully extended it. The king was very angry and did not care about the afterlife. He immediately drew his sharp sword, cut off his right hand, next cut off his left hand, next cut off his right leg, next cut off his left leg, cut off his ears, and cut off his nose. The king asked the sage:
What do you now aspire to?
The sage replied:ğŸ”½I only aspire to the unsurpassed path.

I am now practicing forbearance and will not abandon it for a moment. Even if the king now takes my body and shatters it like mustard seeds, I will never turn back and lose my compassion and forbearance.

When a person is angry and defiled, the wounds after being beaten will bleed immeasurably. Now that I have attained forbearance and my body has been mutilated, milk flows from all my wounds. This is the proof of my practice of forbearance.
Not far away, there were also several hundred sages studying the Way. Hearing that this Bodhisattva had been harmed by the king, they all rushed to the scene and surrounded him, asking:
I wonder if the sage's pain is not too severe?
He replied:
No, it is not so.ğŸ”½
The sages further asked:
Now that your body is shattered into seven pieces, how can you say you have no pain?
The Bodhisattva replied:

Those whose minds are pained but whose bodies are not pained fall into hell, hungry ghosts, or animal realms, while those whose bodies are pained but whose minds are not pained attain unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
At that time, the various sages each exclaimed:
Excellent, excellent!
The forbearance of the immortals is wonderful and unsurpassed. Those with sharp faculties and quick wisdom will certainly fulfill their wishes before long.
Therefore it is said, Forbearance is the foremost.

The Buddha said nirvana is the most supreme. Among the teachings, nothing surpasses nirvana. Nirvana is neither born nor ages, neither sickens nor dies. It is tranquil, without action, without thoughts of arising or ceasing. There is nothing above it in the teachings.
Therefore it is said, The Buddha said nirvana is the most supreme.

Not causing others to be troubled means that those who leave home and abandon wives and children, remove the five desires, give up the world's eight kinds of wrong livelihood, and do not care for worldly glory when leaving home to cultivate the Way, why would they trouble sentient beings in the midst of this?
Therefore, it is said, Not causing others to be troubled.

Harming others is being an ascetic means that as an ascetic one should follow the ultimate truth and the ascetic precepts, not transgressing the sequence, without hatred or deceit towards others, protecting others as if seeing oneself, not following the teachings, and causing progress in learning.
Therefore, it is said, Harming others is being an ascetic.
One's speech should not be coarse, and what is said should accord with one's eloquence.
If one discusses with those of little learning, one will be defeated by them.
One's speech should not be coarse means that when the Buddha was in the world, he spoke the Dharma with MahÄmaudgalyÄyana:
You, MaudgalyÄyana, today!
When speaking the Dharma, one should speak the Dharma according to the Dharma.

In between, it does not allow for mixed meanings. When expounding the true Dharma, the mind and thoughts should be upright. One should not look left and right. How could one floatly speak of matters that are not urgent?
Why is this so?
Coarse words have many flaws and gaps. Later, one will receive another body with a hundred heads, just like the bhiká¹£u KÄtyÄyana.
Therefore, it is said, Words should not be coarse.

As for what is said should be eloquent, one should know the changes and anomalies of astronomy, geography, and the stars, and the calamities that arise from them. One should be well-versed in the six arts and extensively study the classics. If one creates without limit, one will be suspected by the wise. If one is called to account, one's anger will increase tenfold. Such people should not be befriended. Therefore, it is said, What is said should be eloquent.

If one discusses with the ignorant, one will be defeated by them. People have been arguing about right and wrong for a long time. What I say is right, what you say is wrong. We argue with each other, giving rise to anger. It is like two people slandering the Buddha, one who has studied but is not thorough,
and one who has no faith and is dull-witted.
Such two people will receive the seeds of hell, hungry ghosts, and animals. If born as a human, they will be lacking in the six faculties and their speech will be stammering.
Therefore it is said, if one discusses with the ignorant, one will be defeated by them.
Frequently giving rise to afflictions, like a broken vessel,
Repeatedly transmigrating through birth and death, sinking for a long time without a chance of escape.

Repeatedly giving rise to afflictions is like a broken vessel. It is like a person holding onto foolishness until death without changing. The bonds of afflictions, inverted and confused thoughts, and trading in wrong views entangle oneself, like a broken vessel leaking out its contents with nothing left inside. Dust and dirt defile oneself. Therefore, it is said, Repeatedly giving rise to afflictions is like a broken vessel.

Repeatedly transmigrating in birth and death, sinking for a long time without a chance of escape, a person does not anticipate that they will certainly receive misfortune, like a potter's wheel turning without stopping. Dwelling in birth and death for a long time, it is difficult to attain liberation. There is no analogy for it. Therefore, it is said, Repeatedly transmigrating in birth and death, sinking for a long time without a chance of escape.
If one does not afflict oneself, it is like a complete and solid vessel.
Thus, reaching nirvana, forever free from the defilement of dust and dirt.

If one does not trouble oneself, it is like a complete and solid vessel. If one can be self-reliant and not give rise to various attachments and remove the bonds and knots, one will then attain the undefiled faculty of wisdom, the four establishments of mindfulness, the four right efforts, the four bases of supernatural power, the five faculties, the five strengths, the seven factors of awakening, and the eightfold noble path, just like a complete vessel that is capable of receiving and storing. When people see it, they all love and enjoy it. Therefore, it is said, If one does not trouble oneself, it is like a complete and solid vessel.

Thus, reaching nirvana, forever free from the defilements and obscurations, a person without these impurities can reach the place of ultimate nirvana, eternally tranquil, eternally at rest, without arising or ceasing. Therefore, it is said, Thus, reaching nirvana, forever free from the defilements and obscurations.
Health is the greatest gain, contentment is the greatest wealth, trust is the best relative, nirvana is the highest bliss.
As for health is the greatest gain, there are many people in the world who have had minor illnesses since childhood, all due to the fruits of karmic retribution from past lives.
In the past, there were two merchants who braved the dangers of traveling to a foreign country to do business. In just a few days, they accumulated countless wealth.
One of them happened to contract a serious illness. All his wealth was spent on medical treatment, but he did not recover from his severe poverty and illness;
while the other was healthy and did not spend any money. Although he obtained great profits, he still complained,
What I have obtained is not enough to speak of.
When he returned home safely without any loss, he complained day and night about not obtaining more wealth. His relatives advised the merchant,
You are now healthy and have returned home safely. Why do you wail and say you did not obtain profits?
Having a healthy body and life is the most precious treasure.
Therefore, it is said, Health is the greatest gain.
Knowing contentment is the greatest wealth. As explained in the Buddha's Vinaya canon, there are two kinds of people in the world who are difficult to satisfy.
What are the two?
One is to spend money after getting it, the other is to hoard money after getting it.
Even if the heavens were to rain down the seven treasures filling the world and giving them to these two people, they would still not be satisfied.

People who have not severed desires are attached to wealth, seeking more after getting it, not knowing contentment. Only those who practice the Way clearly know impermanence, understand that it is not real, and do not care about treasures. They understand that illusions cannot last long.
It is like seeing lightning when striking stone, passing before the eyes. Such changes come and go without staying.
Therefore it is said, knowing contentment is the greatest wealth.
Knowing relatives are the greatest friends. People commonly know that relatives are based on sincerity and closeness, first trust and then righteousness can be shared.

It is like a person of the past who had deep feelings of love and affection, but only associated with friends and did not speak or interact with his brothers. The government sent a guard to summon this person. The person, being drunk, killed the guard who came to summon him, and then fled to his friends for refuge, telling them the truth of what he had done:
I am now in a perilous situation with nowhere to put my feet. I only ask that you accept me and allow me to escape this hardship.
When his friends heard this, they all exclaimed in astonishment:

Alas! Your great matter is difficult to conceal. You should return immediately and not stay here any longer. If the matter is exposed, the crime will not be small. You have prosperous brothers and relatives. Why do you turn against your own flesh and blood and go to me for refuge?
When that person heard this, he immediately returned home and threw himself at the feet of his brothers, confessing the faults he had committed.
When his relatives heard this, they all comforted him, saying:
Do not be afraid. We will devise a plan to help you escape this difficulty.

The five relatives gathered, prepared the carriage, and set off on their journey to another country. They built a house together and treated each other with respect, surpassing their original country. Their wealth and treasures flourished day by day, and their servants and attendants were countless.
Therefore it is said, Knowing relatives is the foremost friendship.

Nirvana is the foremost bliss means that within nirvana there is ultimately no suffering or affliction. The various bonds of afflictions are forever nonexistent, with no further arising, cessation, or complete extinction. Therefore it is said, Nirvana is the foremost bliss.
Hunger is the foremost affliction, and activity is the foremost suffering.
One who truly understands this will attain the foremost bliss of nirvana.

Hunger is the foremost affliction means that in the past, King Prasenajit was imprisoned by his son AjÄtaÅ›atru in a deep dungeon. People's trust was cut off and provisions were not supplied. He was hungry and destitute, with nowhere to appeal.
The king suddenly thought of the Buddha and remembered the teachings he had heard. He then spoke this verse in the prison:
The supreme teachings flow without end, transmitted and practiced by the world,
truly inexhaustible.
Like the unequaled one's well-taught teachings, when the body is afflicted with suffering, what is worse than the affliction of hunger?
Among afflictions, none is worse than hunger. Therefore it is said, Hunger is the first affliction.

As for action is the first suffering, people in the world have different aspirations and practices. The harshness of hunger, cold, and hardship cutting the body, if a person receives a form, they will have the affliction of dwelling in the dark womb. Even if they descend and receive a form, they will have the torment of a broken body. With all the faculties complete, they will have the distress of decline, aging, and sickness. The body receives and the spirit follows, and they will then receive the rewards of good and evil. This is caused by the actions they have done.
Therefore it is said, Action is the first suffering.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:

One who truly understands this, nirvana is the supreme bliss. When a person practices and seeks eternal tranquility, eternally free from various afflictions, peacefully dwelling in the unconditioned without further suffering and pain, therefore it is said: One who truly understands this, nirvana is the supreme bliss.
Those who pursue goodness are few, while those who pursue evil are many.
One who truly understands this, should quickly seek nirvana.

When a person in the world cultivates goodness, there are few. Although they may practice goodness, their wishes are not fulfilled. If they were to fully practice all wholesome deeds, at that time the gods would only consider humans to be good, and humans would consider the gods to be a hall of blessings.
It is just as explained in the Miscellaneous Sutras, where the Buddha told the bhikshus:
The gods themselves know that the five auspicious signs have arrived, and they all gather together like clouds.
He spoke to the celestial being, saying:
From here, you should wish to be reborn in a good place. When you reach there, you will quickly obtain good benefits. Having obtained good benefits, you will peacefully dwell in the unconditioned.
At that time, the bhiká¹£us addressed the Buddha, saying:
What is it, World-Honored One,
that the gods' good place is a place of great benefit, peacefully abiding in the unconditioned?
What is the meaning of these three phrases?
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
The roots of the Way are complete, shaving the head and face within the true Dharma, wearing the three Dharma robes, not delighting in family affairs, leaving the household life to study the Way.
This is called, bhiká¹£us,
the gods' good place.
What is meant by peacefully abiding in the unconditioned?
The Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
Attaining the contemplation and discernment of the Four Noble Truths.
This is called, bhiká¹£us,
the gods' peaceful abiding in the unconditioned.
Those who practice the Way and cultivate goodness in the world are few, and those who pursue goodness are few.
Those who pursue evil are many. The reason for this is:

Sentient beings who cultivate evil are many, not recognizing the Buddha, not recognizing the Dharma, not recognizing the bhiká¹£u saá¹ƒgha, and also not distinguishing between good and evil, beauty and ugliness, but planting the roots of hell, hungry ghosts, and animals, entering from darkness into darkness without any hope of release, like a blind person holding a torch to illuminate others but not illuminating themselves.
Therefore it is said, Those who go to evil are many.

Those who truly know this and quickly seek nirvÄá¹‡a are those with sharp and dull faculties who awaken differently. Some awaken by hearing, some understand by seeing forms. Therefore the sages spread various teachings, responding to illnesses and presenting medicine without falsehood. Among them, those with sharp faculties observe the myriad changes in the world that are difficult to dwell in the same place. They seek non-action above like saving their head from burning. Why is this?
That place is empty, tranquil, peaceful, and blissful, forever merging with the empty firmament, calming the spirit and unmoving.
Therefore it is said, One who truly understands this will quickly seek nirvana.
There are causes for being born in a good place, and there are conditions for being born in a bad realm,
There are conditions for attaining nirvana, and so it is all due to conditions.
As for there are causes for being born in a good place, what are the conditions?

As for the conditions, they are giving, precepts, hearing wisdom, contemplation, the demeanor of a lay devotee, the demeanor of one who has left the household life, the demeanor of a great practitioner, abandoning wholesome practices and traces - this is called the foundation for the path of causes and conditions. Therefore it is said, there are causes for being born in a good place.
As for there are conditions for being born in a bad realm, what are the causes and conditions?

It is like a person who inwardly harbors resentment and does not open their mind to giving, who violates the precepts, kills, takes what is not given - with such ten unwholesome courses of action that cannot be reformed, they eventually fall and are reborn in the three evil realms. Therefore it is said, there are conditions for being born in a bad realm.

Those who have the causes for parinirvÄá¹‡a, what they say about nirvÄá¹‡a all uses the true path of the sages to sever the various bonds and afflictions, heading forward to the unconditioned, apart from this sage's class it cannot be attained, just like the non-Buddhist brÄhmaá¹‡as say to each other:
In the world there are no causes and conditions, nor any basis or origin. What exists naturally exists, what does not exist naturally does not exist.
How do we know this to be so?
Just like in the wilderness thorns grow with their prickly needles, how could there be a skilled craftsman who shaves off the sharp needles?
Like deer, beasts, and flocks of birds roosting in trees, their fur and feathers are of various colors and appearances, how could there be a person who paints their bodies?
Discussing their different classes and natures, the nature of earth is naturally soft and the nature of stone is naturally hard, how could there be a person who makes them hard or soft?
All of these arise naturally without causes and conditions.
This kind of thinking has been deluded for a long time, they have taught each other and it has continued to the present day, therefore the World-Honored One said:
There is a reason for this, it is not meaningless suffering.
What are the causes and conditions?

When sentient beings practice the ten wholesome [deeds], the land where sentient beings dwell becomes level and even. At that time, pits, high banks, thorns and brambles will naturally become level and smooth;

If there are sentient beings who practice evil, at that time the entire land will give rise to thorns and brambles, high banks and deep pits, and poisonous snakes and insects will breed in abundance. This is all due to the evil accumulated in previous lives.
Therefore it is said, All of this has causes and conditions.
Deer return to the wild, birds return to the sky, principles return to discrimination,
True people return to cessation.
Formerly the World-Honored One was at the side of a sweet fruit garden in the Magadha region, in a stone chamber.
At that time, the World-Honored One, with the pure heavenly eye free from dust and defilements, saw a herd of deer encountering a hunter, fleeing in terror to the perilous mountains.

At that time, the World-Honored One again used his heavenly eye to see a flock of birds avoiding the net and soaring high into the sky. The TathÄgata's heavenly eye also saw the bhiká¹£us' eloquent explanations, gentle and fluent, and immediately that night contemplated the twelve links of dependent origination, thoroughly investigating them in reverse and forward order. The TathÄgata's heavenly eye also saw this. He further saw other bhiká¹£us, who throughout the night contemplated in reverse and forward order, entered the liberation meditation, and as dawn approached and the darkness was about to end, attained parinirvÄá¹‡a in the realm of nirvÄá¹‡a without remainder. This was also observed by the TathÄgata's spiritual eye.

At that time, the World-Honored One contemplated the causes and conditions that gave rise to this meaning, wishing to have his disciples spread the teaching, further enabling the true Dharma to long abide in the world, and causing later generations to behold its great illumination. At that time, the World-Honored One then spoke this verse:
Deer return to the wild, birds return to the sky, meaning returns to discrimination,
true people return to cessation.
Not with a lazy mind, nor with weakness in reaching anywhere,
Desiring to attain nirvana, burning away all bonds and attachments.
Not with a lazy mind, nor with weakness in reaching anywhere - as explained in the Buddha's sutras in the Madhyama Ä€gama, the Buddha told the monks:
This Dharma is cultivated by those with diligence, not by those with laziness. However, those with a lazy nature cannot advance themselves, so how can they skillfully reach nirvana?
It is like a person who is naturally timid and has no two eyes. How can they set their mind to sleeping in the wilderness?

There are many thieves and dangers on the road, difficult to pass through. If one wishes to cross that dangerous place, only with a strong man of courage and valor can they save themselves and be at ease without doing anything;
If one harbors a foolish nature, has deviant thoughts, and believes in inverted views, one will never be able to cross that dangerous place.
Only with the eye of wisdom and the methods of the sages can one then reach the field of non-action.
Therefore it is said: Do not be lazy or timid in reaching anywhere, if you wish to attain nirvana and burn away all attachments.
Monks, quickly bail out the boat, by bailing it will become light,
Permanently severing lustful thoughts, then you will reach nirvana.
Once there was a monk who wanted to cross a river, he encountered a dilapidated boat that was not repaired, at that time the boatman said to the monk:
Wayfarer, if you want to go somewhere, you can use your own strength to bail out this boat, the boat will become light and your body will be safe, where will you not succeed?
At that time the monk used all his strength to bail out the water in the boat, and only then was he able to cross to the other shore.
He put away his robes and arranged his dignified demeanor, gradually going to be close to the World-Honored One. When he arrived, he bowed his head to the Buddha's feet and sat to one side.
The TathÄgata knew that they were ready to be saved, and that was why he looked at them with a serious gaze. This was not something that pratyekabuddhas or arhats could attain.
At that time the World-Honored One then spoke this verse:
Monks, quickly bail out the boat, and by bailing it will become light.
Permanently severing craving and desire, you will then reach nirvana.
At that time the World-Honored One told the monks:
You are now worried about the difficulties of the present, and you are even more afraid of the taboos of the afterlife.

The boat is a perilous and common method of the world, temporarily crossing sentient beings without tiring of it. The body is like a true vessel filled entirely with impurities. Why not abandon it? Baili out the filth and disease, sever desire, anger, and ignorance, and ride the boat of sages to reach nirvana.
I had a self in the past, but now I have no self.
It is neither non-existent nor existent, and cannot be obtained as it is now.

I had a self in the past, but now I do not have a self - the views of non-Buddhist practitioners differ, each considering their own to be correct. My original surname was so-and-so, my original name was so-and-so. Although I had a self, it was non-existent. Although it was non-existent, it existed by itself. It was non-existent and yet self-arisen. Therefore, it is said: I had a self in the past, but now I do not have a self.
Neither non-existent nor existent - non-existent refers to the past, not existent refers to the future, and cannot be obtained now refers to the present.
How can foolish people avoid being like Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as who cling to this crooked path and do not reform themselves?
Why is it so?
Because they do not understand the foremost truth, the path to nirvÄá¹‡a, and they believe in wrong views, not believing in nirvÄá¹‡a.
Therefore, it is said: I had a self in the past, but now I do not have a self. It is neither non-existent nor existent, and cannot be obtained now.
Difficult to see, unmoving, well observed and distinguished,
One should discern the root of the end of craving, which is called the limit of suffering.

The truth that is difficult to see and unmoving, which is well contemplated and discerned, is the ultimate subtlety of the cessation of nirvana, which is formless and invisible. The dharmas of conditioned arising are in motion and do not stop. The formless dharmas cannot be moved. Only the TathÄgata, pratyekabuddhas, and Å›rÄvakas, with the eye of wisdom, well contemplate and discern each and every one. Therefore it is said, The truth that is difficult to see and unmoving, which is well contemplated and discerned.

One should discern the root of the end of craving, which is called the limit of suffering means knowing the root of craving and the arising of various illnesses, and within it, one uproots them forever, cutting them off without remainder. Therefore it is said, One should discern the root of the end of craving, which is called the limit of suffering.
Cutting off craving and removing desire, drying up the river without a trace of flow,
Being able to illuminate this root of craving is called the limit of suffering.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:

Cutting off desire and removing its cravings means that desire is the disease and the root of many afflictions. By uprooting desire, the branches and leaves do not flourish. Within that, one uproots oneself and permanently cuts it off without remainder. The root of desire is naturally extinguished and does not arise again. Desire arises from craving, just like a rushing river that sweeps away living beings. Billions and millions of beings lose their life force and cannot be completely saved. After the river dries up, living beings come and go without any harm. Therefore, it is said, Cutting off desire and removing its cravings, like a dried-up river without a trace of flow.

Being able to illuminate this root of desire is called the end of suffering means that desire is the form and substance, craving is the branches and leaves, and delusion is the nourishing moisture. If a learner contemplates the wonderful contemplation and is able to cut this off, they transcend the end of suffering. Therefore, it is said, Being able to illuminate this root of desire is called the end of suffering.
Seeing what is real and seeing it, hearing what is real and hearing it,
Knowing what is real and knowing it, this is called the end of suffering.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Why is it said to be seeing but actually seeing?
